newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - March 6.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - March 6.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Senator Juan Flavier filed a bill yesterday calling for a constitutional convention whose delegates will be elected in May 1998, along with national and local officials. (MANILA BULLETIN)
- President Fidel Ramos has given Budget Secretary Salvador Enriquez up to March 10 to submit his final report on the inquiry into the sale of a huge tract of land to Amari. (TODAY)
- Former First Lady Imelda Marcos said President Fidel Ramos had promised a hero's burial to late President Ferdinand Marcos. (PHILIPPINE DAILY INQUIRER)
- The Philippines' annual inflation rate fell to a nine-year low in February as food prices fell back after a shortage sent them soaring last year. (ALL PAPERS)
-Ayala Land Inc is diversifying into the manufacture of concrete rooftiles through a partnership with the largest companies in Thailand and the United Kingdom. (TODAY)

- Ayala Corp president Jaime Zobel yesterday announced the appointment of Filemon Berba, president of Globe Telecom, as president and chief executive officer of Manila Water Company, which is a joint venture with Bechtel Corp. Replacing Berba is former Energy Secretary Delfin Lazaro who has been a director of Ayala Corp, Globe and other subsidiaries after his stint in the government. (BULLETIN)

- A consortium of foreign and local firms involved in the development and operation of major infrastructure projects in the Pacific rim countries plans to put up a $1.37 billion rail inland container terminal in the Philippines. The consortium members include Hughes McNaughton Consultants Pty Ltd of Australia, Corporate Investment Funding Ltd of British Virgin Islands and Philippine Coordinated Transport Corp, Amtrust Financial Consultants Inc, both local firms, which will handle development and management of the proposed project. (BULLETIN)
- The Keppel group and two other Singaporean firms have expressed interest in the 50-billion peso north loop railway project of the state-owned Philippine National Railways. (INQUIRER)
